titleStmt.title: Unknown, Ways and Pilgrimages of the Holy Land A 1.1-1.3
Caesarea Maritima: A Collection of Testimonia

publicationStmt.authority: Caesarea City and Port Exploration Project

licence.p: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License.

editorialDecl.p: Authors of testimonia are identified with URIs from The Virtual International Authority File, see http://viaf.org. When multiple VIAF URIs exist, preference has been given to VIAF record linked to the Library of Congress authority file.
Geographic locations are identified with URIs from Pleiades: A Gazetteer of Past Places, see https://pleiades.stoa.org/docs.

When possible, textual works have been cited using URNs according to the Distributed Text Services (DTS) system, see https://distributed-text-services.github.io/specifications. Additional identifiers have been adopted from the systems used by the Perseus Digital Library (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper), Syriaca.org (http://syriaca.org), and other relevant authority systems such as WorldCat Identities or OCLC numbers (https://www.worldcat.org).
Bibliographic items are identified by a unique Caesarea-Maritima.org URI, which is linked, when possible, to OCLC numbers and other identifiers.
Dates have been encoded following the ISO 8601 standard, https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html, and the best practices established for the Sroph√© App, see http://srophe.app.

Languages have been encoded using ISO 639-1 (https://www.iso.org/standard/22109.html), 639-2 (https://www.iso.org/standard/4767.html), and 639-3 (https://www.iso.org/standard/39534.html) codes, following best practices of the TEI guidelines, see https://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/index.html.

taxonomy.desc:
Caesarea-Maritima.org Chronology: This chronology is adapted from the chronology used in The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land
. This taxonomy is used in the catRef encoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.
Caesarea-Maritima.org Testimonia Typology: This typology defines three subsets of testimonia employed by the project and is used in the catRef below to further categorize a given testimonia record.

category.catDesc: A "direct testimonium" contains a word or phrase that is a direct reference to, or name for, the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. When a "direct testimonium" also contains indirect references, the classification by type is nevertheless marked only as "direct".

An "indirect testimonium" makes only an indirect reference to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. This indirect reference may take the form of a common noun or may be implied by context.

A "toponymic testimonium" contains a toponymic epithet related to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs. When a "direct testimonium" also contain a "toponymic testimonium", the testimonium is marked as belonging to both types. These two types do not always overlap and thus our data set also includes "toponymic testimonia" which are not "direct testimonia".

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from Ways and Pilgrimages of the Holy Land A 1.1-1.3 written by Unknown in 1261-1265 CE. This work was likely written in Palestine.

body.desc: Cezaire , Sezaire , and Caesarea are directly attested at Unknown, Ways and Pilgrimages of the Holy Land A 1.1-1.3. This passage was written circa 1261-1265 CE possibly in Palestine.

Two versions of Ways and Pilgrimages of the Holy Land (A and B) survive from the middle of the 13th century, both of which show a close similarity in content to the Holy Pilgrimages. They both trace two circuits for pilgrims, one from Acre across the Plain of Sharon and Ramla to Jerusalem and the other back to Acco from Jerusalem by way of Samaria, but they vary in the density, organization, and content of the geographical and biblical information. Version A, which survives at the Vatican in a manuscript in Old Proven√ßal copied during the 14th century, provides copious detail concerning the sites between Acco and Ioppa. The passage on Caesarea describes sites in the city‚Äôs hinterland as well as in its immediate vicinity or interior.
body.ab: Ces ssont les chamins qui droytament vuet aler de la cit√© d‚ÄôAcre en Iherusalem e les pelerinarges de los sains e les luoqs qui sont en la droyte vie. (1) Qui droytemenc vuet aler en Iherusalem, ci voie en tele manieyra come ilh est en cest escrit devis√©: Primerament l‚Äôon vait d‚ÄôAcre √† Cayphas, au quel chamin ilh i a .iiij. lieuas. Essi apr√®s d‚Äôillueques la Montaingne dou Carme, on le luoc mosseignour saint Danis est, ce est assavoir l√† ont ilh fu n√©s ad une ville que l‚Äôon apele Ffranche ville, auquel luoq est una chapele. Ssos l‚Äôautier ad une pierre val√©e. Au gi√©t d‚Äôune pierre est la Fontaine de mosseignour saint Danis, laquele ilh trova e la fist de ssas propes mayns. E ssachi√©s qui ilh i a mot bieu luoq & es le plus sayn luoq de toute le montanha √† cuer d‚Äôome. (2) En cel√© mees[me] montaingne est l‚Äôabaye de ma dame sainte Marguarite, la quele est de moines, ont ilh i a enssi bieu luoq. Et dessos cele habaye au pendant est le luoq ont saint Helyas habita, auquel luoq est mot bele chapele en la roche. Apr√®s de cela habaye de Sainte Marguarite en le costieira en cele meesme montaigne, y a mot bieu luoq e delitos, hont habitant les ermitans latins que l‚Äôen apele fr√©res dou Carme, ont ilh a une mot bele petite yglise de Nostre Dame. E por tot celuy luoq a grant playnt√© de bones aygues que yehent de la roche de la montaigne; de la quele habaye de Grex iusques as hermitans a une lieua e dymie. Apr√®s y a .j. luoq aval au playn en ssus de la mer, entre Sainte Marguarite e les fr√©res dou Carme, que a nom Anne. Illueq, ssi com l‚Äôen dit, furent fais le clos dont Nostre Seignhor fon clo√©s e encores par le luoc ont ilh furent farg√©s. Apr√®s cele montaigne dou Carme √† la partie des hermitans latins √† la costieira devers Chastieu Pelerin, ssi a .j. luoq que l‚Äôon apela Saint Iehan de Tire, ont ilh i a .j. mostier de Grex, ont saint Iehan ssist motz de biaus miracles. Apr√®s celui luoq vers Chastieu Pelerin, y a une ville que l‚Äôon apele Capharna√ºm, on furent ssais les deniers des quals fu vendu Nostre Ssire. Da Cha√Øphas √† Chastieu Pelerin ssi a .iij. lieuas, le quel chastieu ssi√©t su la mer, e ssu de la maisson dou Temple; & yqui gist ma dame sainte Euphemie, virge e martir. De Chastieu Pelerin √† la cit√© de Cezaire, ssi a .v. lieuas, lequele cit√© est su la mer, & est d‚Äôun baron dou roiaume. Dehors des murs de cele cit√© est une chapele ont saint Corneli gist, que saint P√©re babtiza, lequel ffu apr√®s missire saint P√©re archivesque de cele cit√©. En pr√®s de cele chapele ssi a une mot bele pierre de marm, grant e longe, la quele l‚Äôon apele la Table de Nostre Seignor. Essy i a .ij. autres pierres de ce marbre comme la table, qui ssont toutes rondes, groces dessos et ag√ºes dessus, que l‚Äôen dit les Chandeliers de Nostre Seignor. Apr√®s √† mayn senestra, pr√®s d‚Äôune ville que a nom Pan perdu, ssi est une chapele de Nostre Dame, qui ssi√©t sur le marayns, ont ilh I a molt sain luoq, auquel marays y a molt de cocatrix. (3) De Sezaire ad Arssuf y a .ij. lieuas, le quel chastieu s√©t .j. petit pr√®s de la mer ssur .j. tertre de ssablon, lequel chastieu est de l‚ÄôOspital, au quel chamin par sessus ssi√©t Roche talli√©e & .j. mauvays pays, & l√† sse aubergent males gens aucune ssois por tallier le chamin √† ceaus qui vont √† Iaphe.Ed. Michelant and Raynaud 1882 Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana 3136, folios 19-25

These are the ways that should rightly lead from Acre to Jerusalem and the pilgrimages of the saints and the places that are on the right road. (1) Whoever wants to go to Jerusalem will see how to here, as it is set out in this document. First of all one goes from Acre to Cayphas, a journey of 4 leagues. Also after that (is) Mount Carmel, in the place where my lord St. Denys is, that is to say there where he was born in a town called Freetown (Ffranche ville), where there is a chapel. Beneath the altar there is a precious stone. A stone‚Äôs throw away is the fountain of my lord St. Denys, which he found and made with his own hands. And know that this is a very beautiful place, and it is the healthiest place on the whole mountain in the heart of man. (2) On this same mountain is the abbey of my lady St. Margaret, which belongs to [Greek] monks, where there is also a beautiful place. And below this abbey on the slope is the place where St. Elias lived, where there is a very beautiful chapel in the rock. After this abbey of St. Margaret, on the side of this same mountain, there is a very beautiful and delightful place where live the Latin hermits, who are called the Friars of Carmel; there is a very beautiful church of Our Lady. And throughout that whole place there is a great supply of good water, which issues from the rock of the mountain. From the abbey of the Greeks to the hermits is one league and a half. Afterwards there is a place below in the plain above the sea, between St. Margaret and the Friars of Carmel, which is called Anne. There, so it is said, were made the nails with which Our Lord was nailed; and the place where they were forged may still be seen. After that mountain, Carmel, in the direction of the Latin hermits on the flank facing Pilgrims‚Äô Castle (Chastieu Pelerin) there is a place called St. John of Tira, where there is a monastery of the Greeks, where St. John performed many miracles. After that place towards Pilgrims‚Äô Castle there is a town called Capharna√ºm, where were made the pieces of silver for which Our Lord was sold. From Cayphas to Pilgrims‚Äô Castle is 3 leagues. This castle stands on the sea and belonged to the House of the Temple; and there lies my lady St. Euphemia, virgin and martyr. From Pilgrims‚Äô Castle to the city of Caesarea is 5 leagues. That city is on the sea and belongs to a baron of the kingdom. Outside the walls of that city is a chapel where St. Cornelius lies, whom St. Peter baptized and who after my lord St. Peter was the archbishop of that city. And near that chapel is a very beautiful stone of marble, big and long, which is called the Table of Our Lord. Likewise, there are two other stones of marble like that of the Table that are quite round, thick at the bottom and long, pointed at the top, which are called the Candlesticks of Our Lord. Afterwards, on the left, near a town called Lost Bread (Pan perdu), there is a chapel of our Lady situated above the marsh, where there is a very holy place. In that marsh there are many crocodiles. (3) From Caesarea to Arssuf is 2 leagues. The castle stands close to the sea on a sandy knoll and belongs to the Hospital. On the road above stands Cut Rock (Roche talli√©e), a bad place where evil people encamp from time to time to cut off the road to those going to Iaphe.Rev. Pringle 2018 Pringle (2018, pp. 41, 211 n. 16) identifies the ‚Äúbaron of the kingdom‚Äù (baron dou roiaume) as John Laleman, who last held Caesarea before its fall to Baybars in 1265.

note.p: Rorgo Fretellus, Description of the Holy Places 430-431
Ways and Pilgrimages of the Holy Land B 1.1-1.3
St. John of Tira (al Tira, Tirat al-Lawz)
